channel.description: Technology. Code. Living relentlessly in the real world.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: September
item.description:
Only four films this month…

Rebel Ridge

#FF24 Rebel Ridge is another classic by Saulnier.

From start to finish, the story and action are both shocking and fantastically executed. Aaron Pierre is a star in the making - absolutely electric in this role.

Go into it blind for a good time.

Great.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

Uglies

#FF24 Uglies is a waste of good streaming bandwidth.

If you told me the script was AI generated with the prompt, "generic young adult dystopian fiction" I would not be shocked. There's not a new idea in here, and plenty that is well-trodden.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

The Substance

#FF24 The Substance is a delightful and slightly deranged look at ageing, beauty, and societal pressure.

Moore and Qualley are both fantastic in their respective roles, with Quaid coming in big too. Body horror and satire hits a particularly sweet spot. Again, one to watch cold.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

Wolfs

#FF24 Wolfs is a dry, dark comedy about lone fixers forced to work together.

Pitt and Clooney have good banter together, and the plot has enough layers and threads to keep you going. There's a standout monologue by Austin Abrams too. Runs out of steam towards the end.

Good

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

The September Winner

The Substance could win most months, but Rebel Ridge is too good not to win.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: August
item.description:
Busy month with 11 films in the fight!

Trigger Warning

#FF24 Trigger Warning is the latest Netflix, low-budget action filler.

The acting is flat, the action dull, the plot non-existent. Nothing really holds together in this box-ticking exercise pretending to be a film. Some decent actors absolutely wasted in this.

Avoid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

The Ministry Of Ungentlemanly Warfare

#FF24 The Ministry Of Ungentlemanly Warfare is a big, glossy, comic-book take on World War 2.

I wasn't shocked when I saw Ritchie had directed it - it has his signature quips and bravado all over it. It's also a little style-over-substance, but as silly action goes, it's decent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

The Instigators

#FF24 The Instigators is an odd miss.

It's got a solid cast, a good director, and a decent premise. It's just incredibly formulaic. You've seen this done a million times before, and better. Sometimes films aren't as good as the sum of their parts.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

The Union

#FF24 The Union is yet another Netflix-backed, formulaic action film.

Wahlberg and Berry make it a bit better than much of the slosh being churned out, and there are some reasonable set pieces. The rest is pretty forgettable.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

Jackpot!

#FF24 Jackpot! is a comedy that combines winning the lottery with the purge.

It surprisingly lives up to the bonkers premise, and never takes its foot off the gas. Awkwafina and Cena work well together, with Liu as a nice, late addition. Some fun action too.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

Alien: Romulus

#FF24 Alien: Romulus takes the franchise back to terror in the dark.

A poor choice to deage one actor aside, it treads the line of nostalgia and fan service well, while providing a solid movie. I didn't care for the final act but it doesn't ruin the movie.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

Incoming

#FF24 Incoming is a high-school, gross out comedy that doesn't surprise, but doesn't really have to.

Some fun moments, silly gags, and enough pace to not bore.Clearly the kind of movie you need to be in the right mood for - but perfectly fine if you are.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

Bad Boys: Ride Or Die

#FF24 Bad Boys: Ride Or Die continues the style over substance, buddy action franchise.

Very much fits with the others, which have improved somewhat since Bay stepped away. You're going to get big action, some excellent stunts, and nonsense plot.

Switch your brain off and enjoy

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

Blink Twice

#FF24 Blink Twice isn't for the faint-hearted - covering some dark grounds.

While you'll likely figure out what's going on long before the very graphic reveal, the performances are strong enough to carry the film - particularly Ackie, Tatum, and Arjona.

Good, but not easy.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

Trap

#FF24 Trap is silly, Shyamalan nonsense - the cinematic equivalent of buttery popcorn.

The premise makes little sense, but buy into it and go on the ride - it's pretty fun. Hartnett does a great job in the lead role, even if Shyamalan's daughter as the pop star distracts.

Fun.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

Kingdom Of The Planet Of The Apes

#FF24 Kingdom Of The Planet Of The Apes is a mixed bag.

The world that's been built and the tech used to create it is impressive. However, the story doesn't really take us anywhere wildly new. A little too long, too. It has its moments.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 13, 2024

The August Winner

Somewhat surprised, but Blink Twice is the best of the bunch.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: July
item.description:
Five films for July!

Kinds of Kindness

#FF24 Kinds of Kindness is an interesting triptych of stories of varying quality.

As with all of Lanthimos' work, the stories and their tone are unusual. The middle story the weakest of the three, but a strong cast makes them all work to some degree. Probably a little long

Good

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

Axel F

#FF24 Axel F is another legacy sequel that works to some degree, but misses in others.

There's a little too much "Remember this?" standing in for plot, but Murphy's charm and comic chops help improve some of the otherwise drudging plot. Could do with being a little shorter

Fine

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

Kill

#FF24 Kill is an exceptionally good action film out of India.

It starts as a fine but weak version of The Raid, but becomes far more gruesome at the midpoint. The plot is barely there, but you won't care as you wince through yet another skull-cracking fight.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

Maxxxine

#FF24 Maxxxine rounds out the X trilogy with its weakest, but still good, entry.

Mia Goth is exceptional as the lead, leaning into sleazy 80s movie tropes. The problem is there's nothing here to really wow us - the plot is forgettable and it lacks memorable moments.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

Deadpool & Wolverine

#FF24 Deadpool & Wolverine is 80% fan service, some okay action, and not much plot.

As long as you go in expecting a bunch of moments that barely hold together, it's quite entertaining - the mid-film extended cameos are excellent, for example.

Entertaining trash.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 18, 2024

The July Winner

I think the winner is Kinds of Kindness - I’d happily watch it again in smaller chunks at home.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: June
item.description:
June has four films for us…

Hit Man

#FF24 Hit Man is a fun watch about a man posing as a hit man for the cops.

Powell is very good as the titular character, with the rest of the cast being solid. It's funny, keeps moving along, and has a handful of light twists. Quite light, but enjoyable.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

The Bikeriders

#FF24 The Bikeriders is a sometimes heavy drama about the formation of a biker gang.

Butler sometimes works as the rebel without a cause, but his nihilism leaves him in a plot rut. Comer and Hardy are more interesting to watch. Gripping and dark.

Excellent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

Unfrosted

#FF24 Unfrosted is a badly-paced comedy about breakfast.

The plot seems to have been written around bits, rather than being something that makes sense by itself; unfortunately neither entertain. McCarthy is the only performer who comes out looking okay.

Avoid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

A Quiet Place: Day One

#FF24 A Quiet Place: Day One takes the rural, alien invasion series and moves it to the big city.

The carnage is scaled appropriately, but the human-side is lost. What it gains in spectacle it loses in caring about any of the main characters - well, except the cat.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

The June Winner

The only real choice here is The Bikeriders.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: May
item.description:
A whole seven films for May…

ISS

#FF24 ISS is a somewhat tense but low budget thriller set on the International Space Station after an unknown catastrophe on Earth.

They do a lot with what they have but the back half of the movie drags as we go over the same points again.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

The American Society of Magical Negroes

#FF24 The American Society of Magical Negroes satirizes the trope of black characters who are there to help the white heroes, through the lens of a social media company.

The leads are good, the satirical elements work well enough, but a lot has been done better before.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

The Fall Guy

#FF24 The Fall Guy mixes great stunt-action with breezy comedy.

While the premise and chemistry between the leads doesn't quite work, it's all just a set-up for some big, practical stunt work - which mostly impresses. There's not a tonne else happening but it works.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

Abigail

#FF24 Abigail is a fun, slow-burn horror. You know it's going to go wrong for the kidnapper-protagonists, but it's fun to see exactly how.

Go into this blind and enjoy the slightly ridiculous, over the top second half. The cast certainly seem to be enjoying it.

Worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

Boy Kills World

#FF24 Boy Kills World doesn't really work.

The idea of a silent protagonist in a videogame inspired action film is neat but, beyond a few fun action scenes, the rest is a mess - and a slog. Doesn't achieve much of what it sets out to do.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga

#FF24 Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga has George Miller doing what he does best: directing some of the best, long action sequences on film.

They're kinetic, and with a clarity that few others manage.

There's a story here too - but it's very secondary to the action.

Worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

Mother’s Instinct

#FF24 Mother's Instinct is a middling drama about two friends who slowly turn on each other.

Chastain and Hathaway are excellent as the leads, but the whole thing is dragged down by the "Are they really doing that?" plot that goes on for far too long. You'll stop caring.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 17, 2024

The May Winner

While there are some solid films, I’m struggling to pick a clear winner - I guess Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga has the fewest faults.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: April
item.description:
Very late but only two films for April…

Monkey Man

#FF24 Monkey Man is an interesting entry in the Wick-inspired action genre.

Dev Patel absolutely looks the part and has the presence to pull this off. There are a bunch of very good action scenes, and some where Patel's direction is too wobbly and edited.

Worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

Civil War

#FF24 Civil War is gripping for its entire runtime.

The story is a little more compressed than I'd like, but the performances are excellent; Spaeny is going places. There are some shot choices I want to pour over on a second viewing, but the first was more than enough

Excellent

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

The April Winner

They’re both good but the winner is Civil War.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: March
item.description:
Bit late, but there are six films in the fight this month

Ricky Stanicky

#FF24 Ricky Stanicky is a farcical comedy about an imaginary friend who kind becomes real.

Cena and Efron are as dependable as always. The film is kinda sweet in places, if a little obvious. Not a masterpiece but perfectly watchable.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

Drive Away Dolls

#FF24 Drive-Away Dolls is a comedy that is less than the sum of its parts.

A good cast, a great director, a fine premise - just not many laughs. It's got moments, but there's not enough for the runtime. Not bad just not particularly interesting.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

Dune Part 2

#FF24 Dune part 2 is the epic spectacle that it need to be.

The worm rider looks terrible, but everything else is incredible - the soundtrack is massive, the story feels grand and just alien enough, the performances work. An experience like little else.

Excellent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

Argylle

#FF24 Argylle feels like it missteps on almost every level.

Rockwell and Cavill come out largely unscathed, but the rest of the cast seem confused or bored. The twists are forgettable. The action sequences are visually awful. And the plot? There isn't really a plot.

Avoid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

Road House

#FF24 Road House is a cheap remake.

Gyllenhall is the only thing they’ve put money into, and he's solid. Macgregor is atrocious but looks great in the fights.

There are some genuinely excellent line deliveries but the whole thing is underwritten, and looks cheap.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

Shirley

#FF24 Shirley tells the story of the first black woman to attempt a presidential bid.

It does a good job of showing the difficulties the titular character faces, but not as much showing why we should care about her specifically. A little dry at times but decent.

Watchable.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 14, 2024

The March Winner

The winner is Dune Part 2 and it’s not close. I’d been left a bit cold by part 1 when I first saw it, but warmed to it on second viewing - part 2 just worked for me.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: February
item.description:
An excellent month with 6 movies

Self Reliance

#FF24 Self Reliance is an interesting, and slightly odd, dark comedy about a man who volunteers to be hunted for money.

The film keeps you guessing about a number of aspects of the game that is being played. Johnson and Kendrick keep you engaged throughout.

Good comedy.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

American Fiction

#FF24 American Fiction is an excellent look at society's expectations of race and the prejudice therein.

Wright is excellent, playing comedy and drama equally well, through very light and dark moments. As well as the more overt statements, it has a rich subtext too.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

Suncoast

#FF24 Suncoast is a family drama about a girl whose brother is terminally ill.

It doesn't always find the right tone, and much is about her trying to live her life, rather than a tightly plotted drama - it moves at an okay pace. Linney is excellent as the mother.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

The Iron Claw

#FF24 The Iron Claw looks at the real wrestling family who faced tragedy after tragedy.

The entire cast sell the film incredibly well: physically and in delivery, both in and out of the ring; this could be Efron's best work. One ill-judged dream sequence aside, it's very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

The Zone Of Interest

#FF24 The Zone Of Interest is a powerful look at the Nazis living next door to Auschwitz.

Much of the film is relatively (and intentionally) mundane; dealing with petty family moments, party politics, and life. But the dark underbelly is there and disturbing. Not easy

Excellent

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

Wicked Little Letters

#FF24 Wicked Little Letters is amusing, as it looks at how class and prejudice affected a real case of poison letters.

Colman/Buckley are strong and keep the film moving. The plot, though, is pretty predictable. The letters are mostly too chaste to be consistently comedic.

Fine

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

The February Winner

A very tough one with three movies that could win most months, but I think it’s American Fiction for me; so much more than the trailers showed.

item.title: Film Fight 2024: January
item.description:
Very late, but 10 whole films in the January fight…

Freelance

#FF24 Freelance is an entirely forgettable and slightly ridiculous action film.

Alison Brie is great as always, and John Cena does fine. Clearly on a tight budget for the level of action they wanted, some scenes show that - and a couple look pretty good.

Not bad.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

Priscilla

#FF24 Priscilla is as shocking as it is beautiful.

Cailee Spaeny is perfectly cast as the young lead, through a world far too old for her; marrying a start who is cruel and controlling. The slightly dreamy look lends an otherworldliness to awful moments. Well-paced.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

Next Goal Wins

#FF24 Next Goal Wins is fun but formulaic.

You've seen the beats before: a bad team gains a grumpy coach, and they help each other become better. It's underwritten and obvious, but a perfectly fine film that's reasonably put together. You won't hate it.

Decent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

The Holdovers

#FF24 The Holdovers finds a specific tone, and executes it well.

Giamatti's grumpy, better than thou professor plays perfectly against the troubled but brilliant boy he's asked to look after. Witty dialogue and fun moments, backed by some heartwarming scenes.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

Society Of The Snow

#FF24 Society Of The Snow tells the horrific story of Uruguayan rugby players lost in the Andes.

From the bone-crunching plane crash to the inevitable avalanche, the film doesn't revel in suffering but doesn't back away from it either. Difficult, but powerul.

Very worth seeing

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

Poor Things

#FF24 Poor Things sees Lanthimos embrace the weird in a search for humanity.

The main cast are strong, with Stone putting in a brilliant physical performance. The production deisgn is beautiful, but the wide lenses are intrusive to the point of distraction.

Funny, dark, great.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

Role Play

#FF24 Role Play is a passable action comedy, with some great actors (Cuoco, Oyelowo).

However, the fun, early ideas (like Nighy's extended sequence) get squandered by a generic, action-focussed last act. Easy going, at least, and doesn't overstay its welcome.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

Lift

#FF24 Lift is the most generic of modern heist movies.

It has some incredible and utterly wasted talent (Mbatha-Raw, D'Onofrio) trod through a plot that could be AI generated, with a charmless lead. The action is messy, with far too many cuts.

Boring.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 20, 2024

The End We Start From

#FF24 The End We Start from is a look at motherhood through the lens of an ecological disaster.

The core performances (Comer in particular) are strong, especially as the situation grows more dire. The cameos feel more distracting than useful, but the story is solid enough.

Good

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

The Kitchen

#FF24 The Kitchen is about capitalism displacing those most in need.

The themes are well-worn, but it's reasonably well done, especially within a constrained budget. Kano is good as a reluctant father figure, with the relationship never getting cheesey.

Decent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 25, 2024

The January Winner

Some very good contenders but the winner is Priscilla, a beautiful and disturbing look at celebrity.

item.title: Film Fight 2023: Finale
item.description:
It was a bit more of an uneven year. There were some great films, but fewer in contention than previous years. I also was quite busy so saw fewer films in the cinema

As per the caveat every year, Film Fight is done in a (non particularly serious) knock-out style: it can pick my favourite film of the year, but nothing else. (Also the very idea of a single favourite film is a bit silly.)

The honorable mentions: films that weren’t good enough to win their own month, but still worth seeing.

  • Aftersun
  • Cocaine Bear
  • Knock At The Cabin
  • Infinity Pool
  • John Wick: Chapter 4
  • Missing
  • Extraction 2
  • Asteroid City
  • Blackberry
  • How To Blow Up A Pipeline
  • They Cloned Tyrone
  • The Artifice Girl
  • Barbie
  • The Beanie Bubble
  • Joy Ride
  • The Blackening
  • Inside
  • Past Lives
  • No-One Will Save You
  • Talk To Me
  • Quiz Lady
  • The Killer
  • Dream Scenario
  • The Royal Hotel
  • Killers Of The Flower Moon
  • Godzilla Minus One

And now the monthly winners:

  • January: Tár
  • February: All Quiet On The Western Front
  • March: Women talking
  • April: Tetris
  • May: Beau is Afraid
  • June: Alice, Darling
  • July: Oppenheimer
  • August: Corner Office
  • September: Bottoms
  • October: The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial
  • November: Anatomy Of A Fall
  • December: Maestro

From that, there’s a lot of good stuff to choose from and you’re not going to go wrong with any of it (except maybe Tetris).

We have great but very different courtroom dramas in both The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial and Anatomy Of A Fall, the former being antagonistic and the latter being about what gets mispoken in an argument.

Elsewhere, Tár and Maestro paint very different pictures of obsessive genius, and desire leading to conflict.

I think Bottoms is the first comedy to make it through in a while, but is well deserved - it made me laught more than I thought it would.

We have Women Talking and Alice, Darling showing the consequences of horrific abuse: quietly, then very loudly. Both have stayed with me.

As always, I’m a little torn as to what my favourite film was but I think I’m going to go with Tár - mixing an incredible central performance, with some directing that was stunning.
